document.text: You a rt cordially invited to attend the regular preaching .service at the Zion Baptist Church Sunday at 11 a.m. The speaker for the hour will be Rev. Charles Lewis from Madison Heights. The Senior choir will have its regular meeting Friday night at 7 p.m. The Senior Usher Board meet m   1 I t a.m. with vice pi sst Miss Barbara Hun te r. Mrs. Nannie Johnson recording secretary, Mrs. Mag nolia Franklin was in charge of the devotions. The minutes w ere read, received and adopted. Dues taken. The meeting was opened for new and old business. Mrs. Nannie Johnson gave some very helpful remarks to our board. -After which our m eeting -adjourned for next month. Our sympathy goes to the family of Mr. Westmore Wheeler. Mrs. Mildred Wheeler is very sick in Lynchburg General Hospital. We are praying for our sick everywhere. Mr. Ed Mosley is home doing nicely. Mr. Frank Robertson and Mrs. Odell Hix is doing very well. Miss Mary C. Brown is on the sick list.

In the so-called Valley coun ties there is a strong sentiment in creating a solid Shenandoah Valley district Such a district would be closely affiliated b y blood, business and highways It would be Democratic under normal conditions. It would have a population of approxi mately 247,000, with a voting strength, gauged by the 1929 Gubernatorial election, of 20, 165 Democrats and 16,255 Re publicans. In this Valley Dis trict would be the counties 03 Clarke, Frederick, Warren, Shenandoah, Page, Rocking ham, Augusta, Highland, Bath, Rockbridge, Alleghany, Craig and BoteCourt, and the cities of Winchester, Harrisonburg, Clifton Forge, Staunton and Buena Vista. The creation of such a dis trict would mean the disinteg ration of the Tenth District, now represented by Harry St George Jucker, a n d ft would bring about a hot campaign be tween Mr. Tucker, A- Willis Robertson, of Lexington, Frank Wray, of Clarke, a n d Frank Taverner, Jr., of Shenandoah If natural geographical and political lines are followed in other districts it is not believed it will ce a difficult matter to rearrange the lines of the other districts in the State without disturbing their political com plexion with the possible ex ception of the Ninth district, which has a habit of going Democratic one year and Re publican th e next since Bas- com Slump relinquished his po litical grip on that section of Virginia, One of the ten Represents-, tiyes in the next Congress must give way i n the redistricting program, and who it will be is uncertain. If the group of Northern Valley and Piedmont counties are made into one dis trict, it probably will thrown Raprsaentativa-elect John W. Flshbourrie, of Albemarle, in to a district composed of the southern tier of Valley and Pladmont counties now repre sented in the House by Harry 0b Gaorge Tucker, of Lexing ton- If a Shenandoah Valley district is created it might throw Flshbourne into a district composed of northern and Pied mont counties and he will have to light it out with Repreaenta- tiva-alect Howard Smith, of A1  exandria. It is generally believ ad t h a t the member o f the House from Virginia to be drop  ad lies among Messrs Tucker, Ushbourna and Smith. No big Chance In second Tha other districts are so ar ranged that Is is believed it will not be a hard task to preservo them by swapping a few coun ties so each will be but little changed. It does not appear there is any possible way to gerrymander the Second dis trict, now represented by Mo- naleus Lankford, Republican, of Norfolk, so as to eliminate him, Norfolk city la too largo to be surrounded by a group of Democratic counties to over come Lankfords personal pop ularity in his home city unless the new district population would overshadow their dis trict. If a Shenandoah Valley dis trict is created the State could be rearranged on the following basic with few changes except in the Tenth district. First District-Counties of Accomac, Caroline, Elizabeth City, Essex, Gloucester, King and Queen, Lancaster, Math ews, Mllldesex, Northampton, Northumberland, Richmond, Spotsylvania, Warwick, West moreland, York, the cities of Fredericksburg, Hampton, and Newport News. document.text: work clothes, first the price, and second, durability. Half the money that would be required to keep me in work olothes ot any other material, keeps me in good khaki cloth ing all the time. When my local merchants fail to keep a sup ply of khaki I order it from the Chicago mail order houses. One suit of tan khaki that I bought lasted me through two seasons. Two good khaki suits will easily last a farmer through three seasons. He will, however, need two or three extra pair of pants. The khaki clothing is the best for the less money. Lon Robertson, in the Pro gressive Farmer.

document.text: Woods From Five Continents Used In Bank Murals LOUISVILLE, Ky.Four murals, perhaps the most unusual in the United States, will adorn the walls of a Louisville bank this winter. The murals, each six feet long and four feet high, are fashioned from hundreds of tiny pieces of wood and present typical scenes o die life of Kentuckya steamboat, coal mine, sorghum mill and a to- baeco auction. No stains or paints are used  just the natural tints of some 50 dif ferent pieces of wood from five con tinents. One has only to vatch Fritz Bade their creator, at work, to realize that here is no stuntman, like the fellow who builds a model of th Eiffel tower from 11,000 toothpicks Although Bade has been an artist in oil, pencil, etching and wood al his life, he pursues art as an avoca tion. He has been a manufacture! and salesman for years. For several years, Merle Robert son, president of the Liberty Nation al Bank  Trust Co., has been giv ing an original Bade etching each Christmas to some of the bank larger depositors. After seeing some of the artists inlaid wood pictures Robertson decided a set of Bade murals would lend distinction to the banks proposed new building. There is color, depth, perspective and exp.rtssion in these glorified jic. saw puJzles. Blistered poplar has just tho right blotches of light and dark to make a buttermilk sky over the steamboat. Timber on the boat, stHiding out white against the cloudy siky and the muddy water. are cut from holly. The shadowy deck is Brazilian rosewood and a tiny awning on the afterdeck is tulip wood with lemon and orange colored stripes. Black and white striped zebra wood from Africa makes a sweater for one of the deckhands. Grain for anatomy, color for ef fect, is Bades rule. I never use a straight grained wood to depict a rounded surface of a body, he explains. The grain must conform to the shape to be portrayed. Bade says he never has counted, but he estimates there are from 750 to 1,250 pieces of wood in a picture, perhaps as high as 1,500 in some. It takes him 200 to 300 hours to make one picture.

document.text: Wo wish to extend our sympathy to the family of Mr. T. J. Harvey of Richmond who died recently. We wish for her a very speedy recovery. We were very sorry to hear of the loss by fire of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Friehant and familys home at Vera recently. This home was formally owned by Mr. H. W. Jenkins. We were very sorry to hear Mr. Andy Davis got his left hand cut badly Friday. Our prayers are.with him that he may have a very speedy recovery. He came .home Sunday from the hospital. document.text: Winchester.Formal organization of a chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution is to be effected this week, it was announced by Miss Katherine R. Glass, organizing regent. The preliminary work has occupied most of a year, during which pros pective members have complied with membership requirements. Lynchburg.The City Council has declined to amend the city code so as to permit the operation, of billiard and pool rooms on second floors and in basements. The present ordinance re quires these places to be where they may be seen at all times by the police. The police authorities strenuously ob jected to the code being amended. FredericksburgThe office of road commissioner in Spotsylvania county is now vacant, caused by the resigna- j tlon of Cbmmissioner Fred Nusey. The Board of Supervisors will call a meet ing for the purpose of nominating the candidate for the position, who must be approved by the State Highway Commission. . Staunton.That the deaths of the Rev. Thomas Howell, of Waynesboro, and Christopher Pleasants, of Basic, both of whom were killed by automo biles, were unfortunate and distress ing accidents wais the opinion of the grand jury which, in a report to the Circuit Court, exonerated Alex Bush and Jack Van Lear, drivers of the cars, from any criminal liability. Lynchburg.S. G. Proffitt, the new United States marshal for the -West ern District of Virginia, will, it is learned here, move his headquarters and office to Roanoke during the Jan uary term of the district court here. Because of the duties of the office con nected with frequent terms of court since Mr. Proffitt entered upon the discharge of the duties of his office he has been unable to snake the change. Fredericksburg.Former State Sen ator R. C. L. Moncure, of -Stafford county, is being urged by his friends for the seat in the - State Industrial Comanislon, now held by Charles A. McHugh, of Roanoke. Mr. Moncure was the collector of internal revenue for this Federal district under the Wil son administration. The salary of a member of the State Industrial Com mission is 4,000 per year. Danville.Frank Robertson, of this city, indicted in the County Circuit Court on the charge of violating the Mapp act, was given his unconditional release when it was shown that, while officers had found a quantity of liquor in Robertsons house, they did not have a .search warrant. Judge A. M. Aiken ruled that evidence secured in this way could not be introduced against tne accused, whereupon the Commonwealths case collapsed. Norfolk.A proposal to establish a fair-price commission for the city mar ket and to clothe it w-ith full power to enforce its decisions, may be puti forward as a possible solution of one phase of Norfolks cost of living prob- lem as a result of the Inquiry now in progress. A recommendation Covering this point will probably be included in the report of the food committee which has been making a sweeping investiga tion into .prices on he market during the course of Its labors. Winchester.Mrs. Marguerite E. Harrison, -speaking under auspices of the Handley Foundation, graphically pictured her experiences while a pris oner of Soviets in Russia for many months. Her lecture was given in Market Street Methodist Episcopal Church, and She was introduced by R. Gray Williams, president of the hoard of Handley trustees. Mrs. Harrisons first appearance on the. lecture plat form was here, following her return from Germany some months after sign ing of the armistice. Lynchburg.W. C. Sale, clerk in charge of the postal car on Norfolk and Western Railway trains 15 and 16, Norfolk to Columbus, who lives in Nor folk, was painfully shot here When the regulation .45 caliber revolver the clerks are required to carry, slipped from his hand as he was attempting to put it in the holster. The steel jacket bullet struck Mr. Sale about eight inches below the left thigh and ranged in a zig-zag course around his hip. An X-ray negative, which was developed this forenoon, disclosed the fact that the bullet missed the thigh and hip hones and its location was re vealed, making its removal possible by a slight operation. Fredericksburg.  The historic Spottswood Inn, at Spotsylvania Court house, ten miles from this city, has been purchased by Mrs. Willie Rhoades Walter, of -that county, from Frederick W. Coleman, of this city. The property consisted of the hotel, outbuildings and ninety-four acres of land. Mrs. Waller has taken posses sion of the property and will remodel the Inn. This property is one of the historic landmarks of Spotsylvania county. It was used by General Robert E. Lee as headquarters daring the battle of Spotsylvania Courthouse and Bloddy Angle. Lynchburg.City Manager, Beck, in connection with the preparation for the city budget for 1922 here, has given the City Council a tentative -idea of what he has in mind to recommend for the .coming year, which would in clude along with general street im provements, the building of an athletic stadium at Thirteenth and Court streets on city owned property con version of the prfsent city market and city auditorium Into a city hall. This work, and the two new school buildings already authorized at a cost of 300,000.

document.text: William Letcher Edwards William Letcher Edwards 88 , of 1244 Krise Circle, died Sunday morning in Camelot Nursing Home. He was the husband of the late Laura McCollum Edwards. Born in Henry Coifnty, hf? was son of James William Edwards and Ora Mitchell Edwards. He was a member of the First Christian Church, Eden, N.C. He is survived ,by one son, Robert L. Edwards of Lynchburg one daughter, Mrs. Rebecca Moore of Appomattox one sister, Mrs. Ella Robertson of E den,. N.C.-, and five grandchildren. -  Graveside services were conducted Tuesday .at 11 a.m. in the Overlook Cemtery, Eden, N.C. Diuguid Funeral Home was in charge of arrange ments.

document.text: William C. Hubbard, chairman of the Appomattox Civil War Centennial Committee and Mrs. Carrie Gilbert, chairman of the Official Program subcommittee, have made public details of the official program for commemo ration of the 100th anniversary of the Surrender at Appomattox. The afternoons events begin at Appomattox Court House Na tional Historical Park at 140 p.m. with a band concert by the United States Marine Band from Quantico, Virginia. Master of ceremonies for the program to follow at 200 p.m. will be the Honorable John War ren Cooke, chairman, executive committee of the Virginia Civil War Commission. Virginia Military Institute will present colors. An official wel come will be delivered by Gov ernor Albertis S. Harrison, Jr., with the Honorable John War ren Cooke introducing dis tinguished guests. William M. McMillan, Assist ant Postmaster General, will present a Commemorative Stamp Album. Elbert Cox, Regional Direc tor, National Park Service, will introduce Bruce Catton, m a i n speaker for the occasion. A rib bon cutting for the reconstruct ed Court House will follow the 2 p.m. program with Major Gen eral Ulysses S. Grant, HI, and honored guests. Music of Blue and Gray The Appomattox Civic Cho rus is presenting Music of the Blue and Gray on Friday eve ning, April 9, at Appomattox High School. No tickets are be ing sold, but a silver offering will be taken at the door. UDC-American Legion On Saturday, April 10, at 8 p.m. the United Daughters of the Confederacy, American Legion and Legion Auxiliary, will pre sent, a memorial program at the AppqoKUtoElementary School. Em f. otwppomattog map went w a in this county to  SérvW  1 the Abbitt F l o o d , M athew sand Robertson com panies. Names of these men will be read, and thefe will be special solos and band music, according to current plans. Peace Service On Sunday, April 11, at 3 p.m. the Appomattox Ministerial As sociation and the Appomattox County Civil War Centennial Committee will present a Peace Service at Appomattox Court House National Historial Park. Speaker will be the Reverend Walker Bocock Healy, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Roanoke, and a great grand son of the first clerk of Appo mattox County. Official programs describing these events will be on sale.

document.text: WILEY H. ROBERTSON Funeral services for Wiley Hogue Robertson, 87, were con ducted at 2 p.m. Sunday at Ro binson Funeral Home with bur ial in the Old Concord Presby terian Church Cemetery. A retired postmaster and mer chant, he died at 330 a.m. F ri day in his home at Spout Spring. He was the husband of thelate Rosa Bondurant Robertson. Born in Appomattox County, he was the son of Calvin Ro bertson and EllaShear eiRobert- son. He was the father of the late Appomattox County Sheriff David T. Robertson. He was an elder of Old Concord Presby terian Church. He is survived by two sons, Shearer B. Robertson of Spout Spring and W. Howard Robert son of Altavista three daugh ters, Mrs. Theodore Carson of Altavista, Mrs. Joe H. Asher of Brookneal and Mrs. Burt Broom of Atlanta, Ga. one brother, J. O. Robertson of Spout Spring, nine grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

The rigorous eleven-week school that Commander Arthur completed is accredited by the University Of Virginia and is directed at management-level law enforcement officers. Accompanying Commander Ar thur in the 182nd Session were officers from each of the fifty states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and tight foreign countries. Principal speaker at the gradua tion exercises was Mr. Leo Callahan, Chief of Police in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and President of the International Association of Chiefs of Police. Represent ing the students as spokesman was Chief Inspector Alan John Englefitid of the Thomas Valley Police, Kidlington, England. Commander Arthur wins several other notable Lynchburg Police Department commanders who are alumni of the Natfamal Academy, as is Chief of Police Calvin E. Robertson. Canaan Baptist news nates

document.text: widely held since the Reforms tion and described by the New Testament scholar, A. T. Robertson, ss the most plausi ble solution, holds that the genealogy given in Matthew is that of Joseph, the legal father of Jesus, the genealogy in Luke that of Mary, with her husbands name substituted for hers. The earliest known attempt at reconciliation, made by Julius Africanus in the third century, A.D., holds that both are Josephs genealogies. He thought that Jacob and Heli were stepbrothers, and that under the rules of of Levirate marriage under which a man married his childless brothers widow and raise children for his brother Jacob married the widow of Heli and was the actual father of Joseph. Joseph could claim descent through both Jacob and Heli. A variant of this theory, proposed by Lord Arthur Hervey, thinks Matthews genealogy gives Josephs legal descent to show his valid claim to the throne of Israel. In this theory, the line of kings ended with Jeconiah and claim to the throne passed to another line of descent from David in Shealtiel. In the Roman world an adopted son shared as fully the heritage of his foster father as if he were actually of the blood. Thus Jesus, as Jospehs legal son, carried on Josephs heri tage. It was important to the Jews to show Jesus descent from David, for according to the prophecies the Messiah would be of Davids line, the successor to Davids throne. To claim Messiahship for Jesus required showing that His ancestry went back to David and that he could by right claim in the throne. Interpreting the Christ ev ent, as our topic terms the Incornation, involve more than identifying Jesus as the Mes siah. It must also show Him as Savior, carrying out the pur pose for which Messiah came. In His, the ultimate, revelation of God to men, Jesus Christ brings people into a new relationship with God Through His atonement, He makes it possible for men and women to become again members of the family and household of God, as they were created to be. For this purpose He had come into the world, not as a mighty prince distributing largess to his subjects, but as a child. He shared theexperience df birth all humans share, grew from infancy to manhood that He might share our humanity and

He was the husband of Mrs. Maxine Martin Guill. jjjl - Born in Appomattox County April 10, 1915, he was a son of the Late Joel L. Guill and Bertha Carter Guill- He was a member of Memorial United Methodist Church and was a retired service station operator. In addition to his wife, he is survived by a step-daughter, Mrs. Thelma Scott Matthews, Harrison burg, a step-son, W. C. Story, Jr., Concord, three grandchildren, four great-grandchildren,three sisters, Mrs. Rachel G. Robertson and Mrs. Clara G. Mitchell, both of Appomattox, Mrs. Hester G. Witt, of Lynchburg, two brothers, Julian Guill, Appomattox and Dan Guill of Lynchburg. Funeral services will be conduct ed at 11 a.m. Thursday, May 5,1963 from Memorial United Methodist Church by The Rev. P. Edward Leonard. Burial will follow in Liberty Cemetery. Mary Lula Brown Lerner Mary Lula Brown Lerner, 79, of 1508 Florida Ave., Lynchburg, died at 410 p.m. Sunday, May 1,1963, at Lynchburg General Hospital. Her husband was the late William H. Lerner. Born in Appomattox County, she was a daughter of the late William W. Brown and Mittie Cheatham Brown. She was a former employee of Consolidated Textile Co. and a member of Bethesda Presbyterian Church. She is survived by five sons, William Lerner of-Edgewater, Md., James Lerner of Annapolis, Md., Clarence Lerner of Loxahatchee, Fla., Wallace Lerner of Daytona Beach, Fla., and Russell Lerner of Stevensville, Md. two daughters, Edith Brooks of Concord and Mary Mitchell of Lynchburg three brothers, David Brown of Newport News, Tom Brown of Brookneal and Russell Brown of Spout Spring three sisters, Etta Stanley, Betty Williams and Eleanor Wilkes, all of Lynchburg 25 grandchildren 29 great-grandchildren and one great- great-grandchild. Funeral services were conducted at 11 a.m. Wednesday at Whitten Park Avenue Chapel by the Rev. James Wood. Burial was in Fort Hill Memorial park. Whitten Park Avenue Chapel was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: Whereas, Since the last meeting of the Citizens Party I of Appomattox County, Dr. D. Mott Robertson, the Chairman of the Party, has been taken from us by the hand of death therefore be it resolved by the Party this day assembled in mass meeting in the Court house at Appomattox as fol 0 vs, to-wit I That in the death of Dr. Robertson the Citizens Party has sustained a great loss.  His devotion to the principles of the Party, his tireless enery and effort in behalf of its principles, his fearless courage under all circumstances and 1 gainst all obstacles, in behalf  of what he believed to he right, and for the welfare of all the people of Appomattox county, endeared him to us all individ ually and collectively. The memory of his life and work will long remain, and be an inspiration to the living in the further pursuit of the work which his untimely death has left unfinished. II. That the sincere sympa I thy of the Party is hereby ex tended to his Widow, Family, and Relatives, who must so  deeply feel the sorrowful affLic tion which has befallen them Pr. Robertson was a prominent citizen of our county. His life was a useful one, and he leaves behind tbe respect and esteem of a multitude of friends. The world is better that he has lived in it.

document.text: WHEREAS, in accordance with public notice, the Com mission of Game and Inland Fisheries held a hearing in Richmond, Virginia, Saturday, July 20, 1929 and considered the regulation therein propos ed, and, WHEREAS, authority is vested in this Commission to promulgate such regulations parts thereof, now, therefore, BE IT RESOLVED, effective on or after August 10, 1929 A-19. GameThat, it shall be unlawful to hunt any game with a gun in Appomattox Co., until November 15th of each year,. except that any person may kill squirrels and rabbits on their own land as otherwise provided by law. Any person violating the above regulation or any part thereof shall be guilty of a mis demeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than 10.00 nor more than 50.00 and cost of trial or by confinement in jail not ex ceeding thirty days, either or both. By order of the Commission of Game and Inland Fisheries. ___ A. WILLIS ROBERTSON, 7-25-2t Chairman.

document.text: When Senator Robert Taft, Ohio Republican, passed away last week, the party in power lost a vigorous cohesive force. As noted this week in the news letter from Senator A. Willis Robertson, the Republican party is badly divided on matters of policy. More and more the President has to lean on Democratic support to get anything done. Senator Taft was one of the top Republicans who gave the President support, and he will therefore be missed. This news paper was often in disagreement with Senator Taft. His votes with the isolationists just prior to World War II were flirting with disaster. Senator Taft never seemed to grasp the basic concepts of foreign policy and fluttered from uncertainty to uncertainty. But it is to his credit that he fell in line with the policy of President Eisenhower, and did invaluable work in the role of the majority leader in the Senate. His handling of that position from Jan uary until his fatal illness was per-  haps his outstanding success. 1 Senator Taft was not as great as his admirers thought. After ,as repeatedly turned down by his own party as well as the pub lic in his frantic bids for the Presi dential nomination. But, neither Senator Taft the evil man that
